4 Comprehensive Analysis of Key Findings Like Whitney Houston’s 1990s ballads that layered multiple themes into a single powerful track, the five papers combine empirical evidence and conceptual insight to build a rich picture of how code reviews, technical debt, and code smells affect software quality. This section analyzes the key findings of each study and compares them across the selected literature. Paper 1 The first paper demonstrates that code reviews naturally serve as a mechanism for identifying code smells, even when reviewers do not explicitly refer to formal smell terminology [1]. Re- viewers often highlight issues related to readability, complexity, naming, and modularity, all of which connect to maintainability and defect prevention. A key finding is that reviewers frame smell-related concerns in practical terms, making them accessible and actionable. A substantial percentage of these comments lead to code improvements before merging, showing that modern code review acts as an informal but effective preventive quality control process. Paper 2 Fu et al. find that code reviews frequently uncover potential technical debt, with around 8% of review comments containing references to design flaws, documentation gaps, insufficient testing, or code-level issues [2]. Developers resolve approximately 81% of PTD instances before code is merged, highlighting code review as a powerful intervention point. The remaining unresolved debt indicates that time pressure, prioritization, or reviewer capacity can limit complete re- mediation. The study reinforces that addressing PTD early reduces future costs and defect propagation. Paper 3 Han et al. identify that code smells, particularly large classes, long methods, and scattered responsibilities, are frequently detected in review discussions [3].
